questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with no comorbidities presented with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers of both hands along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no other illnesses and she says these episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold climates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Primary Raynaud’s phenomenon

Explanation:

This patient has Primary Raynaud's phenomenon because:

  • Young female (age 20-40 years, female: male ratio 5:1)
  • No underlying condition
  • Symmetric involvement
  • Cold trigger

Raynaud's Phenomenon

Primary Raynaud's:

  • Young female (age 20-40 years, female: male ratio 5:1)
  • No underlying disease
  • Normal nail fold capillaries showing regular hairpin loops
  • Accounts for >50% of cases
  • Better prognosis
  • Improves in 15%, progresses in 30%
  • Classic triphasic colour changes

Secondary Raynaud's: (Option B)

Common causes include:

  • Connective tissue diseases (especially scleroderma: 80-90%) (Option D)
  • Arterial occlusive diseases
  • Blood dyscrasias
  • Drugs (ergot, beta-blockers, bleomycin)
  • Occupational (vibrating tools)

Clinical Features:

  • Sequential colour changes: White (Ischemia) → Blue (Deoxygenation) → Red (Reperfusion)
  • Triggered by cold exposure or emotional stress
  • It may affect fingers, toes, nose, ears
  • It can be associated with pain, numbness, or paresthesias

Treatment:

  • Conservative: Warm clothing, avoid cold temperatures, smoking cessation
  • Medications for severe cases:
    • Dihydropyridine Calcium Channel Blockers
    • Alpha-1 Blockers- Prazosin
    • Phosphodiesterase-5 Inhibitors
    • Topical Nitroglycerin
    • Digital sympathectomy in refractory cases


Cold sores (Option C) are caused by the virus Herpes and present as small, fluid-filled blisters that appear on the lips, mouth, nose, or cheeks. Given the absence of any comorbidities or underlying diseases, the association of symptoms with cold temperatures or stress, and the characteristic colour changes during episodes, the most likely diagnosis, in this case, is primarily Raynaud's phenomenon.

questions.text: A patient with giant cell arteritis presented with headache, jaw claudication, polymyalgia rheumatica, and mononeuritis multiplex. What should be the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Steroids

Explanation:

  • The symptoms suggest the diagnosis of Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), for which the first line of treatment is administering steroids.

Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA):

  • GCA is an inflammatory condition of medium and large-sized arteries
  • Earlier called temporal arteritis due to temporal artery involvement
  • It's a systemic vasculitis affecting carotid artery branches and the aorta and its major branches
  • It occurs almost exclusively in people over 50 years
  • Shows strong female predominance
  • Genetic associations: HLA-DR4 and HLA-DRB1*04 variants
  • Strong association with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR):
    • 40-50% of GCA patients have PMR
    • 10-20% of PMR patients later develop GCA

Clinical Manifestations:

  1. Common Symptoms:
    • Fever
    • Headaches
    • Malaise and fatigue
    • Anorexia and weight loss
    • Sweats
    • Arthralgias
    • Scalp pain
    • Jaw claudication
  2. Complications:
    • Ischemic optic neuropathy leading to blindness
    • Strokes
    • Scalp/tongue infarction
    • Large vessel complications (in up to 1/3rd of patients):
      • Subclavian artery stenosis
      • Aortic aneurysms (thoracic > abdominal)
      • Risk of aortic rupture or dissection

Treatment Protocol:

  1. Initial Management:
    • Prednisone 40-60 mg/day for 1 month
    • IV methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 days if ocular symptoms
    • Aspirin (Option D) 81 mg daily to reduce cranial ischemic complications
  2. Additional Therapies:
    • Tocilizumab (anti-IL-6) FDA approved (Option B)
    • Given as 162 mg SC weekly/biweekly with steroids
    • Methotrexate as alternative steroid-sparing agent
  3. Monitoring:
    • Treatment typically needed for ≥2 years
    • ESR/CRP is useful for monitoring
    • 60-85% have symptom recurrence during tapering
    • Watch for glucocorticoid toxicity (35-65% of patients)

 

Abatacept (Option A) can be used to treat giant cell arteritis along with prednisolone to reduce the risk of relapse. However, it is not the first-line treatment.

Aspirin (Option D) is not the first-line treatment for giant cell arteritis and is only prescribed for cases with high ischemic risks.

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody(ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Systemic sclerosis

Explanation:

  • Numbness in fingertips and tightened face with ANA finding positive and nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence suggest systemic sclerosis.

Dermal Manifestations of Systemic Sclerosis (SSc):

  • Bilateral Symmetrical Skin Thickening: Begins distally in the fingers and progresses proximally.
  • Skin Pigmentation Changes:
    • Early diffuse tanning without sun exposure.
    • Hypopigmentation with a "salt-and-pepper" appearance on the scalp, upper back, and chest is common in dark-skinned individuals.
  • Sclerosis of Skin and Loss of Appendages:
    • Leads to hair loss, reduced sweating, xerosis, and itching.
    • Disappearance of transverse finger creases and fixed flexion contractures causing muscle atrophy.
  • Fixed Contractures: Affects wrists, elbows, and knees due to skin and tendon fibrosis.
  • Neck Skin Ridges: Firm adherence to platysma muscle limits neck extension.
  • Facial Changes ("Mauskopf"):
    • Taut, shiny skin with loss of wrinkles and reduced mobility.
    • Thinned lips, prominent perioral radial furrows, and microstomia.
    • Pinched, beak-like nose.

 

 

  • Telangiectasia: Dilated capillaries on face, hands, lips, and oral mucosa; correlated with microvascular disease severity.
  • Skin Ulcerations:
    • Chronic ulcers on fingertips, PIP joints, and bony prominences heal slowly and may become infected.
    • Fingertip ischemia leaves fixed digital "pits."
  • Acro-Osteolysis: Resorption of terminal phalanges due to ischemia.
  • Calcinosis Cutis:
    • Dystrophic calcifications in the skin and soft tissues, commonly in patients with anti-centromere antibody–positive lcSSc.
    • Calcific deposits vary in size and may ulcerate, causing pain, infections, or nerve compression.

Immunofluorescence:

  • The nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence detecting Th/To autoantibodies.

Incorrect Options:

Sjögren's Syndrome (Option B) is an autoimmune disorder primarily affecting moisture-producing glands, leading to dry mouth and eyes, gritty eye sensation, fatigue, joint pain, etc.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option C) is a multisystem autoimmune disease that can affect many organs. Common manifestations include a malar (butterfly) rash, joint pain, kidney problems, and blood abnormalities. While SLE may cause numbness or tingling due to nerve involvement, its ANA pattern is typically homogeneous or speckled, not nucleolar.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option D) primarily affects the joints, causing inflammation, pain, and stiffness. It does not typically involve numbness of the fingertips or the tightening of the face seen in systemic sclerosis. Additionally, the nucleolar pattern on ANA immunofluorescence testing is not associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal haemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Takayasu arteritis

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of forearm claudication, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain with weak femoral pulses point to the diagnosis of Takayasu arteritis.

Takayasu Arteritis ("Pulseless disease"):

General features:

  • Predominantly affects young females (<20 years)
  • Vascular Involvement:
    • A leading cause of renal artery stenosis in India
    • Most commonly affects the left subclavian artery
    • Characteristic ostial narrowing vs. diffuse involvement in atherosclerosis

Clinical Features:

a) Early Phase (Pre-pulseless):

  • Systemic symptoms: fever, malaise, night sweats
  • Arthralgias, anorexia, weight loss

b) Vascular Phase:

  • Arm claudication
  • Unequal blood pressure between arms
  • Pulseless disease (difficult to appreciate radial artery)
  • Hypertension (32-93%)

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Young female with renal artery stenosis:
    • India: Think Takayasu arteritis
    • USA: Think fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD)
  • Arm claudication:
    • Rule out neurogenic claudication (cervical disc disease)

Investigations:

  • ESR/CRP elevation
  • Mild anaemia
  • Elevated immunoglobulins
  • Investigation of choice: MR angiography (MRA)
  • Complete imaging of the aorta and major branches is needed

Management:

  • First Line: Steroids (40-60mg prednisone/day)
  • Second Line: Methotrexate (up to 25mg/week) for steroid-refractory cases

Important Points for Differential Blood Pressure:

  • Normal difference between arm-leg BP: <20 mmHg
  • Conditions with unequal arm BPs:
    • Takayasu arteritis
    • Supravalvular aortic stenosis with Coanda effect
    • Preductal coarctation of aorta

Major complications: Heart failure, stroke, MI, aneurysm rupture, renal failure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Polyarteritis nodosa (Option A) presents non-specific symptoms like weakness, malaise, headache, abdominal pain, and myalgia. These symptoms do not align with the given scenario.

Thromboangitis obliterans (Option B) or Buerger disease affects the small to medium arteries and veins and presents with ischemic signs and symptoms in the regions of the distal arteries of the upper and lower limbs. In this condition, claudication is seen in the arch of the foot and calf and is also called the Raynauds phenomenon.

Microscopic polyangiitis (Option D) is a rare autoimmune disease where there is small vessel necrotizing vasculitis that manifests as systemic symptoms involving the kidneys (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis), lungs (diffuse alveolar haemorrhage, chronic interstitial fibrosis), skin (palpable purpura, urticaria, nodules, etc), GIT (bleeding), and CNS (peripheral neuropathy).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with Iritis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rheumatoid arthritis

Explanation:

  • Iritis, also known as anterior uveitis, is inflammation of the iris and ciliary body. It can occur as a result of various underlying conditions. Among the options given, Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is not typically associated with iritis. But conjunctiva and sclera are usually involved.

Systemic Associations and Masquerades of Anterior Uveitis:

  • Infectious Causes:
    • Herpes Infections: Varicella Zoster, Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)
    • Tuberculosis (TB)
    • Syphilis
    • Leprosy
  • Non-Infectious Causes:
    • With Systemic Association:
      • Sarcoidosis
      • Behçet's Disease (Option B)
      • HLA-B27 Associated Arthritis
      • Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Ulcerative Colitis (UC) (Option C) > Crohn's Disease
      • SLE (Option A)
    • Without Systemic Association:
      • Drug-Induced: Pilocarpine, prostaglandin analogues
  • Masquerade Syndromes:
    • Definition: Conditions that mimic the symptoms of anterior uveitis but are not primarily inflammatory in nature.
    • Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Lymphomas
      • Anterior Segment Melanoma
      • Retinoblastoma
      • Metastasis
    • Non-Neoplastic Masquerades:
      • Intraocular Foreign Body
      • Old Retinal Detachment
      • Pigment Dispersion Syndrome
      • Coats' Disease

 

Sarcoidosis is a multisystemic inflammatory disorder involving >2 organs. Iritis is one of the ocular manifestations of sarcoidosis.

Behcet's disease is a rare autoimmune condition characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, skin lesions, and uveitis. Uveitis, including iritis, is a well-known ocular manifestation of Behcet's disease.

Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the colon and rectum. While its primary manifestations are related to the gastrointestinal system, extraintestinal manifestations can occur, including ocular involvement. Uveitis, including iritis, can occur in patients with ulcerative colitis.

questions.text:
A lady presents with recurrent bluing of her hands, stretching of her skin, difficulty swallowing, and lung lesions. What is the pattern of ANA and the diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anti-centromere pattern, CREST

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of recurrent bluing of hands (Raynaud's phenomenon), skin tightening (sclerodactyly), difficulty swallowing (esophageal dysmotility), and lung lesions is consistent with systemic sclerosis (SSc), particularly the limited cutaneous form known as CREST syndrome.
  • In CREST syndrome, anti-centromere antibodies (ACA) are characteristically present, producing a centromere-staining pattern on ANA testing, as given in the image.

 

CREST Syndrome is characterized by the following features:

C: Calcinosis cutis (calcium deposits in the skin).

R: Raynaud’s phenomenon (episodic vasospasm leading to bluing of the hands).

E: Esophageal dysmotility (causing difficulty swallowing).

S: Sclerodactyly (tight, shiny skin of the hands).

T: Telangiectasias (dilated capillaries visible on the skin).

Pattern

Image

Description

Clinical Associations

Centromeric


 

Fine, discrete speckling of the centromere of chromosomes
  • Systemic Sclerosis (especially limited form, CREST syndrome)
  • Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD).

Nucleolar

(Option B)


 

Large, prominent nucleoli within the cell nucleus
  • Systemic Sclerosis (particularly in patients with interstitial lung disease)
  • Polymyositis
  • Sjögren's Syndrome.

(Option D)

Smooth, uniform staining of the entire nucleus
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
  • Drug-induced lupus
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA).

Intense staining of the nuclear membrane or periphery

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), highly suggestive of SLE, especially with associated anti-dsDNA antibodies.

(Option A)

  • Associated with skin dryness, itching, and musculoskeletal pain.
  • Life-threatening when lungs or heart are severely involved.
  • Acute, severe high blood pressure can lead to kidney damage.

  • Skin Pigmentation Changes:

  • Sclerosis of Skin and Loss of Appendages:
    • Leads to hair loss, reduced sweating, xerosis, and itching.
    • Disappearance of transverse finger creases and fixed flexion contractures causing muscle atrophy.
  • Fixed Contractures: Affects wrists, elbows, and knees due to skin and tendon fibrosis.
  • Neck Skin Ridges: Firm adherence to platysma muscle limits neck extension.
  • Facial Changes ("Mauskopf"):
    • Taut, shiny skin with loss of wrinkles and reduced mobility.
    • Thinned lips, prominent perioral radial furrows, and microstomia.
    • Pinched, beak-like nose.
  • Telangiectasia: Dilated capillaries on face, hands, lips, and oral mucosa; correlated with microvascular disease severity.

Incorrect Options:

Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (Option A) is positive for anti-centromere antibody or ACA.

Raynaud’s phenomenon (Option C) is one of the characteristic presentations of diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Some body parts, like the fingers and nose, feel numb and cool in response to cold temperatures or stress.

Peutz-jeghers syndrome (Option D) is an inherited condition that increases the risk of hamartomatous polyps in the GIT and cancers in the GIT and that of the breast, testicles, and ovaries. Since there are no polyps, PJS is unlikely to be the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman complains of dryness in her mouth and eyes and has positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies. The image below shows a positive test result with a score of less than 5 mm in 5 minutes without anaesthesia.



What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sjogren Syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical features of dry eyes and mouth with a Schirmer’s test ≤5 mm/5 min and positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies suggest the diagnosis of Sjogren syndrome.

Sjogren syndrome

Pathogenesis:

  • Sjogren Syndrome is an autoimmune disorder primarily affecting the exocrine glands.
  • The pathogenesis involves lymphocytic infiltration (mainly T and B cells) into exocrine glands, especially the salivary and lacrimal glands.
  • A complex interaction of genetic predisposition, environmental factors, and abnormal immune response triggers this infiltration.
  • B-cell hyperactivity: Characterized by hypergammaglobulinemia and autoantibody production (e.g., anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB).
  • Epithelial cell role: Exocrine gland epithelial cells may express autoantigens (Ro, La), produce pro-inflammatory cytokines, and express Toll-like receptors, facilitating immune activation​.
  • Genetic predisposition: Certain HLA alleles (e.g., HLA-DQA1*0501) and immune-regulatory genes (IRF5, STAT4) increase susceptibility.

Clinical Features:


The hallmark symptoms are xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). Other symptoms include:

  • Oral symptoms: Dry mouth, difficulty swallowing, increased dental caries, and parotid gland enlargement.
  • Ocular symptoms: Gritty sensation, burning, decreased tear production.
  • Systemic involvement: Fatigue, joint pain, Raynaud’s phenomenon, and increased risk of lymphoma, particularly marginal zone B-cell lymphoma​.

Diagnosis of Sjogren Syndrome: Diagnosis involves clinical features supported by specific tests.

Tests:

Any of the following is present:

  • Unstimulated whole saliva flow rate ≤0.1 mL/min
  • Schirmer’s test ≤5 mm/5 min on at least one eye
  • Ocular staining score ≥5 (or van Bijsterveld’s score ≥4) on at least one eye

And, any of the following:

  • Serum antibodies - Anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB
  • Minor salivary gland biopsy (A labial biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration with a focus score ≥1).

Treatment:
Treatment is largely symptomatic and involves:

  • Ocular symptoms: Artificial tears and, if needed, topical cyclosporine for inflammation.
  • Xerostomia: Regular sips of water and pilocarpine or cevimeline to stimulate saliva.
  • Systemic disease: Hydroxychloroquine for mild symptoms and in severe cases, immunosuppressants like rituximab​.

Scleroderma (Option A) antibodies are anti-Scl-70 and anti-centromere. Hence this is not the diagnosis here.

Dehydration & Lacrimal duct stones (Option B & C): Dehydration & Lacrimal duct stones are unlikely since this patient tested positive for anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies which are characteristic of Sjogren syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 30% is associated with Hepatitis B

Explanation: 30% of polyarteritis nodosa is associated with Hepatitis B.

Polyarteritis Nodosa:

  • A multisystem, necrotizing vasculitis of small- and medium-sized muscular arteries. (Option A)
  • Characteristically involves renal and visceral arteries.
  • Kidneys: Arteritis without glomerulonephritis; glomerulosclerosis may be seen in hypertensive patients.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa-like vasculitis may be seen in 30% of patients with hepatitis B, with circulating immune complexes composed of hepatitis B antigen and immunoglobulin.
  • Pathology and Pathogenesis:
    • Vascular lesion: Necrotizing inflammation of small- and medium-sized arteries.
    • Lesions are segmental, involving bifurcations and branches of arteries.
    • In acute stages: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils infiltrate vessel walls and perivascular areas, causing intimal proliferation and degeneration.
    • In subacute and chronic stages: Mononuclear cells infiltrate, leading to fibrinoid necrosis, lumen compromise, thrombosis, infarction, and hemorrhage.
    • Aneurysmal dilations up to 1 cm in size are characteristic.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Nonspecific symptoms: Fever, weight loss, malaise, weakness, headache, abdominal pain, myalgias.
    • Renal involvement: Hypertension, renal insufficiency, hemorrhage due to microaneurysms.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance (eosinophilia is rare).
    • Anemia of chronic disease.
    • Elevated ESR and CRP.
    • Hypergammaglobulinemia may be present. (Option B)
    • Hepatitis B and C screening is essential.
  • ANCA is rarely present. (Option C)
  • Diagnosis: Based on biopsy of involved organs (e.g., nodular skin lesions, painful testes, nerve/muscle) for vasculitis findings.
  • Treatment:
    • Prednisone and cyclophosphamide significantly improve survival.
    • In patients with hepatitis B or C, antiviral therapy should be included along with glucocorticoids and plasma exchange.

  • Telangiectasia: Dilated capillaries on face, hands, lips, and oral mucosa; correlated with microvascular disease severity.
  • Skin Ulcerations:
    • Chronic ulcers on fingertips, PIP joints, and bony prominences heal slowly and may become infected.
    • Fingertip ischemia leaves fixed digital "pits."
  • Acro-Osteolysis: Resorption of terminal phalanges due to ischemia.
  • Calcinosis Cutis:
    • Dystrophic calcifications in the skin and soft tissues, commonly in patients with anti-centromere antibody–positive lcSSc.
    • Calcific deposits vary in size and may ulcerate, causing pain, infections, or nerve compression.

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A) has symmetrical involvement of small joints, morning stiffness lasting for more than 1 hour, and classical deformities in severe cases. The given scenario does not include symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option C) presents with fatigue, joint pain, photosensitive rash, mouth ulcers, and hair loss. The given clinical scenario is not of SLE.

Pneumonia (Option D) is an infection of the pulmonary parenchyma, classified into community-acquired (CAP), hospital-acquired (HAP) and ventilator-associated (VAP). It does not present as the given scenario. It presents with fever, cough with characteristic sputum, chest pain, headache, chills, etc.

questions.text: Which condition necessitates the use of anti-nuclear antibodies for accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are autoantibodies that target components within the cell nucleus. They are important diagnostic markers for various autoimmune diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of a wide range of autoantibodies, including ANAs. ANA testing is a valuable tool in the diagnosis of SLE, as it helps to detect the presence of these antibodies in the patient's blood. The most common ANA pattern seen in SLE is a homogeneous (diffuse) pattern, although other patterns can also be observed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Scleroderma: ANAs are also present in scleroderma, another autoimmune disease, but their presence is not specific for scleroderma alone. Additional antibodies such as anti-centromere antibodies (ACA) and anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) antibodies are more specific for scleroderma diagnosis.

Option C. Drug-induced lupus: Drug-induced lupus is a condition that can occur as a result of certain medications, and it shares some clinical features with SLE. However, ANAs are not typically required for the diagnosis of drug-induced lupus. The presence of ANAs in drug-induced lupus is less common and usually of lower titer compared to SLE.

Option D. Sjogren's syndrome: ANAs are present in the majority of patients with Sjogren's syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth. However, the hallmark autoantibodies in Sjogren's syndrome are anti-SSA (Ro) and anti-SSB (La) antibodies. These antibodies are more specific for the diagnosis of Sjogren's syndrome than ANAs alone.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common clinical feature observed during the progression of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C. Arthralgia & myalgia

Explanation:

  • Musculoskeletal involvement is the most common clinical feature in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).
  • Arthralgia (joint pain) and myalgia (muscle pain) occur in the majority of patients, often as initial symptoms.
  • SLE commonly presents with polyarthritis or polyarthralgia that resembles rheumatoid arthritis, but is typically non-erosive.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male has had chronic hypercalcemia for the last 1.5 years, but PTH levels are normal. Which of the following is most likely the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sarcoidosis

Explanation:

  • From the given history, the patient has chronic hypercalcemia but PTH is normal. This means the hypercalcemia is PTH-independent. Sarcoidosis, due to extra-renal production of calcitriol by activated macrophages, presents with hypercalcemia.

Sarcoidosis:

  • Multisystem granulomatous disease of unknown etiology, characterized by non-caseating granulomas. In sarcoidosis, activated macrophages inside the granulomas express 1-α-hydroxylase, converting 25-hydroxyvitamin D into 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). This leads to increased intestinal calcium absorption and persistent hypercalcemia.
  • Because the calcium level is high, the parathyroid gland decreases PTH secretion, explaining the normal or low PTH levels in such cases.

Feature

Details

Pathology

Non-caseating granulomas in multiple organs

Common Sites

Lungs, lymph nodes, skin, eyes

Lab Findings

↑ Serum ACE, ↑ calcium, normal/low PTH

CXR

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy

Diagnosis

Clinical + radiological + biopsy confirmation

Treatment

Glucocorticoids for symptomatic disease

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Malignancy (Option A) – Can cause hypercalcemia via PTHrP or bone metastasis, but presentation is usually acute and associated with systemic symptoms like weight loss; chronic stable picture is less likely.

Parathyroid hyperplasia (Option C) – Would cause elevated PTH, not normal PTH.

Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) (Option D) – Causes hypocalcemia initially due to phosphate retention and decreased calcitriol synthesis; later may cause secondary/tertiary hyperparathyroidism with raised PTH, not normal.

questions.text: A child presents with kawasaki disease with multiple small coronary artery aneurysms. Treatment is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Aspirin for 6 weeks:

Explanation:

  • In Kawasaki disease patients with small coronary artery aneurysms, low-dose aspirin is continued for about 6 to 8 weeks to prevent thrombosis as the aneurysms may regress over time.
  • The 6-week duration covers the period of highest thrombotic risk during vascular remodeling.
  • Early IVIG administration is also critical during the acute phase to reduce aneurysm

Incorrect Options:

Aspirin lifelong (Option A): Reserved for large or giant aneurysms with persistent risk of thrombosis.

Aspirin for 4 weeks (Option B): Typically used when no coronary involvement is present.

Aspirin and clopidogrel for 6 weeks (Option D): Dual antiplatelet therapy is usually reserved for larger aneurysms or specific thrombosis risk cases, not routine small aneurysms.

questions.text: A patient presents with morning stiffness and tests positive for anti-CCP antibodies. Which of the following histological features is most characteristic of the underlying disease?

choices.text: Pannus formation and erosive joint damage

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pannus formation and erosive joint damage

  • Anti-CCP antibodies are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The hallmark histopathological finding in RA is pannus formation - a hyperplastic granulation tissue composed of inflammatory cells, fibroblasts, and synovial cells, which invades cartilage and bone, leading to erosive joint damage and deformities.

Rheumatoid arthritis

Epidemiology

  • Male to female ratio - 1:3
  • Peaks between 25 and 55 years
  • Remains constant between 55 and 75

Genetics

  • Strongly associated with the HLA-DRβ1 gene
  • Higher concordance in monozygotic twins

Triggers and suppressors

  • Cigarette smoking and infections can trigger RA in genetically predisposed individuals by citrullination of proteins.

Non-caseating granulomas (Option B): Characteristic of sarcoidosis, not RA.

Subepidermal blister with IgA deposits (Option C): Seen in dermatitis herpetiformis, associated with celiac disease.

Tophi with monosodium urate crystals (Option D): Pathognomonic for chronic gout, not RA.

questions.text: Patient presents with dry cough, dyspnea and stridor since 1 month. HPE of hilar LN shows stellate granulomas with giant cells and circular lamellated concretions on histopathology. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sarcoidosis

Explanation: The presence of stellate granulomas with giant cells and lamellated concretions (Schaumann bodies) in hilar lymph nodes is characteristic of sarcoidosis.

  • Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease of unknown etiology, often involving the lungs and intrathoracic lymph nodes.
    • Non-caseating granulomas, giant cells, asteroid bodies, and Schaumann bodies are typical histopathological findings.
    • The patient’s respiratory symptoms, stridor, and mediastinal lymphadenopathy support this diagnosis.

Asteroid Bodies:

  • Asteroid bodies are stellate or star-shaped structures seen within the cytoplasm of giant cells.
  • They are composed of aggregated proteinaceous material consisting primarily of fibrin.

Schaumann Bodies:

  • They are concentrically laminated, basophilic structures found within the cytoplasm of giant cells.
  • They comprise calcium and proteinaceous material, such as mucopolysaccharides and immunoglobulins.

Schaumann bodies Schaumann bodies- magnified

Tuberculosis (Option B): Shows caseating granulomas with central necrosis, not the non-caseating granulomas with Schaumann bodies seen in sarcoidosis.

GPA (Option C): Characterized by necrotizing granulomas and vasculitis affecting the upper/lower respiratory tract and kidneys; histology does not show lamellated concretions.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Option D): Features loosely formed interstitial granulomas without Schaumann bodies; usually history of antigen exposure (e.g., mold, bird droppings).

questions.text: Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibody in systemic sclerosis is most commonly associated with which of the following manifestations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Interstitial Lung Disease

Explanation: Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibody is strongly associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and a high risk of developing interstitial lung disease (ILD), particularly pulmonary fibrosis.

  • This antibody is both a marker of disease severity and a predictor of poorer prognosis in systemic sclerosis.

Pulmonary Features in Systemic Sclerosis (SSc):

  • Major Forms of Lung Involvement:
    • Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) and Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) are the primary lung issues and leading causes of SSc-related death.
    • The coexistence of ILD and PAH worsens survival rates significantly.
  • Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD):
    • Evidence of ILD on HRCT in up to 65% of patients, with clinically significant ILD in 16–43%.
    • Risk factors: Male sex, African-American race, diffuse skin involvement, severe GERD, and presence of Scl-70 autoantibodies.
    • Progressive early decline in FVC (within 3–5 years).
    • Symptoms: Exertional dyspnea, fatigue, dry cough, and Velcro crackles at lung bases.
    • HRCT shows lower lobe subpleural reticular opacities and ground-glass opacities; the extent of ILD on HRCT predicts progression and mortality.
    • PFTs show restrictive defects and reduced DLCO, often with exercise desaturation.
  • Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH):
    • Affects 8–12% of SSc patients as a late complication, often coexisting with ILD.
    • Defined by elevated mean pulmonary artery pressure (≥20 mmHg) with normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (≤15 mmHg).
    • Risk factors: Limited cutaneous disease, older age at onset, and certain autoantibodies (e.g., anti-centromere).
    • Symptoms progress from exertional dyspnea to angina, syncope, and right heart failure.
    • Exam findings: Loud pulmonic component of S2, tricuspid regurgitation murmur, elevated JVP, peripheral edema.
    • Screening: Annual echocardiography; cardiac catheterization for definitive diagnosis.
  • Other Pulmonary Complications:
    • Includes aspiration pneumonitis, pulmonary hemorrhage, obliterative bronchiolitis, pleural reactions, chest wall fibrosis, spontaneous pneumothorax, and increased risk of lung cancer.

Cardiac Manifestations of Systemic Sclerosis (SSc):

  • Detected in 10–50% of SSc patients, more common in diffuse cutaneous SSc (dcSSc) than limited cutaneous SSc (lcSSc).
  • Cardiac involvement correlates with worse outcomes in SSc.
  • Types of Involvement:
    • Pericardial: Includes pericarditis, pericardial effusions, constrictive pericarditis, and rarely, cardiac tamponade.
    • Myocardial: Patchy myocardial fibrosis due to microvascular involvement, vasospasm, and ischemia-reperfusion injury leading to left ventricular systolic or diastolic dysfunction and potentially heart failure.
    • Endocardial: Often silent but may contribute to overall dysfunction.
    • Conduction Abnormalities:
      • Common conduction system fibrosis, with potential heart block, premature ventricular contractions, atrial fibrillation, and supraventricular tachycardia.
    • Myocarditis:
      • Acute or subacute myocarditis may lead to left ventricular dysfunction, best detected by cardiac MRI or endomyocardial biopsy.

Raynaud's phenomenon (Option B): Common in systemic sclerosis, but it is not specifically linked to anti-Scl-70; seen in both limited and diffuse types, often associated with anti-centromere antibodies in limited cutaneous form.

Calcinosis cutis (Option C): More often linked to the limited form of systemic sclerosis and the CREST variant, not to anti-Scl-70.

Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (Option D): “Watermelon stomach” occurs in systemic sclerosis but is not specifically correlated with anti-Scl-70; more frequent in limited disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with flaccid bullous lesions as shown in the image below involving the entire trunk and oral cavity. Acantholytic cells are seen on Tzank smear. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pemphigus vulgaris

Explanation:

  • As the patient is presenting with flaccid bullous lesions involving the entire trunk and oral cavity, along with the presence of acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear, the most probable diagnosis would be Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • However, a definitive diagnosis would require additional clinical evaluation, including a biopsy and direct immunofluorescence testing.

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV):

  • PV is the most common chronic autoimmune blistering disease caused by antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins.
  • They are characterized by the presence of flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid present on normal skin or an erythematous base.
  • The blisters rupture producing painful erosion.
  • Mucosal involvement is a very important and one of the distinguishing features of PV.

Histopathology:

  • Intraepidermal cleavage with acantholysis (detached keratinocytes) primarily localized to the suprabasal region
  • Separation of basal keratinocytes along the basement membrane zone, resulting in an appearance that resembles a "row of tombstones"
  • The target antigens for PV are most commonly Desmoglein 3 and sometimes Desmoglein 1. The image below shows the common target antigen in Intraepidermal Immunobullous Disorders.

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely itchy skin condition that is associated with celiac disease caused by gluten insensitivity.. It is characterized by clusters of small, intensely itchy vesicles and papules on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, and buttocks.

Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disorder that primarily affects the elderly. It is characterized by tense bullae that typically occur on the flexural surfaces of the body, such as the armpits and groin.

questions.text: A patient presented with uveitis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis. Which of the following is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HLA-B27

 

Explanation:

The combination of uveitis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and other spondyloarthropathies, which are strongly associated with HLA-B27.

 

Ankylosing Spondylitis

 

Clinical Features

General Features

Spine and Joint involvement

Extra-articular manifestations
  • Inflammatory back pain: Gradual onset, worse with inactivity, improves with movement and is often associated with early morning stiffness.
  • Fatigue: A common and significant symptom.
  • Postural changes: Loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, and forward stooping of the neck.
  • Enthesitis: Inflammation at tendon or ligament attachment sites, often mistaken for fibromyalgia.
  • Peripheral joint involvement: Affects large joints like hips, knees, and shoulders and is usually asymmetrical.
  • Sacroiliac joint involvement: B/L and asymmetrical; pain may radiate to the buttocks or posterior thighs.
  • Reduced spinal mobility: Limited movement in the lumbar region due to inflammation and pain, often accompanied by muscle spasms.

 
  • Anterior uveitis: Most common extra articular manifestation. Presents with sudden unilateral eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity, often preceding joint symptoms.
  • Anaemia, prostatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, aortic valve disease, and very rare cases of amyloidosis or upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis
  • Osteoporosis: This can lead to vertebral fractures, especially with spinal fusion.


 

Investigations of Ankylosing Spondylitis

Tests

MRI

  • HLA-B27: The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a strong indicator of AS. The prevalence of AS in the general population is less than 0.5%.
  • Inflammatory Markers: Elevated ESR and CRP levels may indicate active disease.
  • Faecal Calprotectin: Helps screen for associated inflammatory bowel disease.

Show characteristic changes in sacroiliac joints, such as:

  • Blurred cortical margins
  • Erosions and sclerosis
  • "Pseudowidening" of joint space (early stages)
  • Joint space narrowing and fusion (later stages)
  • Bamboo spine - Vertebral body fusion by syndesmophytes
  • Dagger sign - Calcification appears as a single radiodense line vertically running down the spine on frontal radiographs.
  • Investigation of choice – more sensitive than X-rays for detecting early inflammatory changes.
  • Can reveal bone marrow oedema, enthesitis, synovitis, and erosions.

questions.text: A male patient presents with oral ulcers and ulcers in the anal canal. He is diagnosed with Behçet's disease. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?

choices.text: Ulcer over the dorsum of the penis
It is more similar to Crohn's disease than ulcerative colitis
Pathergy test positive is a criterion of ISG diagnostic criteria

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulcer over the dorsum of the penis

 

Explanation:

Ulcers over the dorsum of the penis are not typically associated with Behçet’s disease, which more commonly presents with genital ulcers on the scrotum or glans penis, rather than the dorsum.

 

  • Behçet’s Disease is a chronic, multisystemic vasculitis characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and systemic involvement.
  • It is an immune-mediated disorder that primarily affects small and medium-sized blood vessels.

 

Behcet’s Disease- Pathogenesis and Clinical Features

Category

Features

Clinical Significance

Pathogenesis
  • T-cell mediated immunity
  • Th1 cell activation
  • Elevated cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α)
  • Neutrophilic vasculitis
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • Auto-inflammatory rather than autoimmune
  • Affects vessels of all sizes
  • Treatment targets inflammation

Mucocutaneous
  • Oral ulcers (97-99%)
  • Genital ulcers (>80%)
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Pathergy reaction
  • Often initial presentation
  • Oral ulcers heal without scarring
  • Genital ulcers leave scars

Major Organ Involvement
  • B/L uveitis (>50%) (Option C)
  • Vascular (25%)
  • Neurologic (5-10%)
  • Arthritis (non-erosive)
  • More severe in males
  • Ocular disease can cause blindness
  • Vascular involvement can be fatal
  • Presents similar to IBD (Crohn's disease > Ulcerative colitis) (Option B)

Behcet’s Disease- Diagnosis and Management

Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria (ITR-ICBD)

Two Points Each:

  • Genital aphthosis
  • Ocular lesions
 

One Point Each:

  • Oral aphthosis
  • Skin lesions
  • Vascular manifestations
  • Positive pathergy (Option D)

≥3 points needed for diagnosis

Laboratory Findings
  • Non-specific inflammation markers
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • ESR, CRP elevation
  • Leukocytosis

Helps rule out other conditions

Required Investigations
  • Ophthalmologic examination
  • Pathergy test
  • Skin biopsy if needed
  • Imaging, based on symptoms

Confirms involvement and monitors complications

Treatment

  • Colchicine 1-2mg/day
  • Topical steroids
  • Topical sucralfate

Refractory: Systemic steroids, azathioprine

Ocular Treatment
  • Anterior: Topical steroids
  • Posterior: Steroids + azathioprine

Refractory: TNF inhibitors

Major Organ Involvement
  • Vascular: High-dose steroids + cyclophosphamide
  • Neurologic: High-dose steroids + immunosuppression

Requires aggressive therapy and monitoring

questions.text: A patient presents with joint swelling, a pan systolic murmur, negative rheumatoid factor (RF), and elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute rheumatic fever:

  • Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF):

    • ARF is an inflammatory disease that can develop after a Streptococcus pyogenes infection (such as strep throat). It commonly presents with migratory arthritis (joint swelling), carditis (which can present as a pan-systolic murmur), and other systemic symptoms. The elevated ESR indicates inflammation, and the negative rheumatoid factor helps distinguish it from rheumatoid arthritis.

  • Joint Swelling and Murmur:

    • The presence of joint swelling and a pan-systolic murmur (suggestive of mitral regurgitation due to carditis) is characteristic of ARF. The negative RF and elevated ESR further support this diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (RA): Although RA can present with joint swelling and an elevated ESR, a pan-systolic murmur is not typical of RA. Additionally, RA would usually involve symmetrical joint involvement and is less likely to cause heart murmurs.

Option C - Juvenile spondyloarthropathy: This condition typically affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, not typically presenting with a pan-systolic murmur or significant joint swelling in the way described.

Option D - Ankylosing spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis primarily affects the axial skeleton and does not usually present with joint swelling or a pan-systolic murmur.

questions.text: After confirming a diagnosis of gout, which of the following drugs is a purine analog that would be most appropriate for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Allopurinol

Explanation:

  • Allopurinol is the first-line choice for gout management. It is a purine analog that acts as a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, effectively reducing uric acid production.

The drug works through dual mechanisms: direct inhibition of xanthine oxidase and competition with phosphoribosylpyrophosphate in the salvage pathway.

Allopurinol:

  • Allopurinol is the first-line treatment for the prevention of gouty arthritis, particularly in patients who are overproducers of uric acid.
  • The initial dose is typically 100 mg daily, with a target urate level of <5-6 mg/dL and can be titrated up to 800 mg as needed.
  • In patients with renal impairment, dose adjustments are essential.
  • Adverse effects:
    • Stevens-Johnson syndrome
    • Toxic epidermal necrolysis
    • Acute gout flare-up, which may occur due to rapid urate level reduction
  • To prevent flare-ups, anti-inflammatory therapy should be continued until the patient is normouricemic and has not had an attack for 3-6 months.

 

Capecitabine (Option B) is a pyrimidine analog used in breast cancer treatment. This medication has no role in gout management and does not affect uric acid metabolism.

Cytarabine (Option C) is a cytosine arabinoside and pyrimidine analog used in chemotherapy. It is not indicated for gout treatment and does not influence uric acid levels.

Febuxostat (Option D) is also a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. While effective for gout, it is not a purine analog.

Incorrect Options:

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experiences skin thickening, muscle weakness, and pale peripheries upon cold exposure. Her creatine kinase is increased with positive ANA, and biopsy revealed scl-70 positivity and perifascicular infiltration. What is the antibody linked to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Anti PM /Scl antibody

Raynaud’s phenomenon and scl-70 positivity signify systemic sclerosis (diffuse). The peri fascicular infiltration and raised creatine kinase signify the presence of dermatomyositis/ polymyositis. Hence, this is called overlap syndrome (dermatomyositis/ polymyositis + systemic sclerosis), and the antibody linked to this combined scenario is Anti PM/ Scl antibody.

  • Overlap Syndrome occurs when dermatomyositis (DM) or polymyositis (PM) coexists with other connective tissue diseases (CTDs), such as scleroderma, mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD), Sjögren’s syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), or rheumatoid arthritis.

Polymyositis

questions.text: 40 year lady presents with difficulty in eating due to persistent dry mouth. She also has grittiness in eyes due to dry eyes. On examination, dental caries is noted with enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Possible diagnosis is:

Definition

Dermatomyositis is a chronic, inflammatory myositis seen in adults around 50-60 years of age.

Clinical features

Clinical features

  • It presents as symmetrical muscle weakness (proximal > distal)
  • Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly papules over knuckles) are pathognomonic of the disease.
  • Gottron’s sign: Symmetric, confluent, violaceous macular erythema (CMVE) on the back of fingers, on the extensor surfaces of joints of the elbows, knees, or ankles

questions.text: A patient presented with sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitations of the lung, and renal failure. Which of the following is the most useful investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Test for ANCA

Explanation: The clinical scenario of sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx (upper respiratory tract), nodular lesions with cavitation in the lungs (lower respiratory tract), and renal failure strongly suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis. The most useful investigation in this case is a test for ANCA.

 

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA):

  • GPA is a vasculitic disorder characterized by granulomatous inflammation of the upper and lower respiratory tracts, small vessel vasculitis, and pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.
  • Pathology and Pathogenesis:
    • Hallmarks: Necrotizing vasculitis and granuloma formation in affected organs.
    • Organs involved:
      • Lungs: Nodular cavitary infiltrates; necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis.
      • Kidneys: Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis with minimal immune complex deposition.
      • Upper airway: Granulomatous inflammation, necrosis, nasal septal perforation, and saddle nose deformity.
      • Immune imbalance: Predominantly Th1-mediated cytokine response with elevated IFN-γ, TNF-α, and IL-12.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Respiratory tract: Paranasal sinus pain, nasal discharge (purulent/bloody), subglottic stenosis, cough, hemoptysis, and dyspnea.
    • Renal: Proteinuria, hematuria, red blood cell casts, and progressive renal failure.
    • Skin: Palpable purpura, ulcers, or nodules with vasculitis.
    • Ocular: Conjunctivitis, episcleritis, retro-orbital masses, and proptosis.
    • Neurological: Mononeuritis multiplex, cranial neuritis, or cerebral vasculitis.
    • Systemic symptoms: Malaise, fever, weight loss, arthralgia, and fatigue.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Biopsy:
      • Lung biopsy: High diagnostic yield, showing granulomatous vasculitis.
      • Renal biopsy: Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.
    • Serology: Antiproteinase-3 ANCA positivity (~90%).
  • Treatment:
    • Induction Therapy: Glucocorticoids, cyclophosphamide or rituximab
    • Maintenance Therapy: Azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil or methotrexate

Biopsy to show granuloma (Option B): While granulomas may be seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), their absence does not exclude the diagnosis. Biopsy findings are supportive but not definitive, and testing for ANCA is less invasive and provides earlier diagnostic information.

AFB staining of sputum (Option C) is primarily used for diagnosing tuberculosis, which does not match the clinical presentation of combined upper and lower respiratory tract involvement with renal failure seen in GPA.

BAL (Bronchoalveolar Lavage) (Option D) can help evaluate lung involvement and detect inflammatory cells but is not specific for GPA. ANCA testing is more specific and less invasive for confirming the diagnosis in this case.

  • Unequal blood pressure between arms
  • Pulseless disease (difficult to appreciate radial artery)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:

It is primarily used as an immunosuppressant in organ transplantation and certain autoimmune conditions but is not typically recommended as an initial treatment for RA due to it’s inconsistent efficacy and high toxicity.

 

Sulfasalazine (Option A) is one of the disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) commonly used in the treatment of RA. It helps reduce inflammation and joint damage and is considered a first-line treatment option for RA.

 

Hydroxychloroquine (Option B) is another DMARD used in the management of RA. It has anti-inflammatory properties and can help control symptoms and slow disease progression. It is often prescribed as a first-line treatment option, especially in mild to moderate RA.


Methotrexate (Option C) is widely recognized as the first-line DMARD for the treatment of RA. It is highly effective in reducing symptoms, preventing joint damage, and improving long-term outcomes. Methotrexate is considered the anchor drug and is often prescribed as the initial treatment for most patients with RA.

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Ankylosing Spondylitis

  • The young man's early morning backache, stiffness improving with exercise, and persistent red eyes suggest ankylosing spondylitis (AS), a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints. Key features include morning stiffness, back pain relieved by activity, and reduced lung expansion (<3 cm) due to costovertebral joint involvement. Persistent red eyes indicate uveitis, a common extra-articular manifestation. X-ray findings may reveal the characteristic "bamboo spine" due to vertebral fusion from chronic inflammation.

Ankylosing Spondylitis - Clinical Features

General Features

Spine and Joint involvement

Extra-articular manifestations
  • Inflammatory back pain: Gradual onset, worse with inactivity, improves with movement and is often associated with early morning stiffness.
  • Fatigue: A common and significant symptom.
  • Postural changes: Loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, and forward stooping of the neck.
  • Enthesitis: Inflammation at tendon or ligament attachment sites, often mistaken for fibromyalgia.
  • Peripheral joint involvement: Affects large joints like hips, knees, and shoulders and is usually asymmetrical.
  • Sacroiliac joint involvement: B/L and asymmetrical; pain may radiate to the buttocks or posterior thighs.
  • Reduced spinal mobility: Limited movement in the lumbar region due to inflammation and pain, often accompanied by muscle spasms.
  • Anterior uveitis: Most common extra articular manifestation. Presents with sudden unilateral eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity, often preceding joint symptoms.
  • Anaemia, prostatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, aortic valve disease, and very rare cases of amyloidosis or upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis
  • Osteoporosis: This can lead to vertebral fractures, especially with spinal fusion.

Tests

X-rays

MRI

  • HLA-B27: The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a strong indicator of AS. The prevalence of AS in the general population is less than 0.5%.
  • Inflammatory Markers: Elevated ESR and CRP levels may indicate active disease.
  • Faecal Calprotectin: Helps screen for associated inflammatory bowel disease.

  • Blurred cortical margins
  • Erosions and sclerosis
  • "Pseudowidening" of joint space (early stages)
  • Joint space narrowing and fusion (later stages)
  • Bamboo spine - Vertebral body fusion by syndesmophytes
  • Dagger sign - Calcification appears as a single radiodense line vertically running down the spine on frontal radiographs.
  • Investigation of choice – more sensitive than X-rays for detecting early inflammatory changes.
  • Can reveal bone marrow oedema, enthesitis, synovitis, and erosions.

questions.text: What extra-articular manifestation is commonly observed in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subcutaneous nodule:

  • Subcutaneous nodules are the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • These nodules typically develop over bony prominences or pressure points and are often found on the extensor surfaces of the forearms and elbows.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sjogren's syndrome: While Sjogren's syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, can occur in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, it is not the most common extra-articular manifestation of the disease.

Option C - Felty's syndrome: Felty's syndrome is a rare complication of rheumatoid arthritis characterized by the triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia. It occurs in a small percentage of patients with rheumatoid arthritis but is not the most common extra-articular manifestation.

Option D - Vasculitis: Vasculitis, inflammation of blood vessels, can occur in rheumatoid arthritis but is not the most common extra-articular manifestation. It is less common compared to subcutaneous nodules.

questions.text: What is the next recommended investigation to aid in diagnosing the condition of a patient who has cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ANCA:

  • The patient's presentation of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy is suggestive of small vessel vasculitis.
  • ANCA testing is a valuable investigation in such case.
  • ANCA is a group of autoantibodies that target neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens.
  • Two main patterns of ANCA are recognized: cytoplasmic (c-ANCA) and perinuclear (p-ANCA).
  • c-ANCA is typically associated with antibodies against proteinase 3 (PR3) and is seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis).
  • p-ANCA is associated with antibodies against myeloperoxidase (MPO) and is seen in microscopic polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome).

Incorrect Options:

Option B -  RA factor (rheumatoid factor): Rheumatoid factor is an autoantibody commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). While RA can involve multiple systems, including joints, it is not typically associated with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Therefore, performing RA factor testing is unlikely to provide relevant diagnostic information in this case.

Option C - HbsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen): Hepatitis B infection can present with various clinical manifestations, but cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are not commonly associated with hepatitis B infection. Therefore, testing for HbsAg is unlikely to help diagnose the underlying condition in this case.

Option D - MIF (migration inhibitory factor): Migration inhibitory factor is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that has been implicated in various inflammatory conditions. However, it is not specific to any particular disease or diagnostic entity. Testing for MIF alone would not provide sufficient diagnostic information to identify the underlying cause of the patient's presentation with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: Common neurological tumour in NF-2?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vestibular Schwannoma:

  • Bilateral Vestibular Schwannomas are most common tumor seen in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Optic glioma: Optic gliomas are tumors that affect the optic nerve. While they can be seen in other conditions such as neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1), they are not typically associated with NF-2.

Option C - Café-Au-Lait macules: Café-au-lait macules are pigmented skin lesions that can be seen in both NF-1 and NF-2. However, they are not tumors and do not specifically indicate the presence of a neurological tumor.

Option D - Neurofibrosarcoma: Neurofibrosarcoma is associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.

questions.text: What is the accurate description of marble Schonberg disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Osteopetrosis:

  • Osteopetrosis (Marble Bone/Albers Schonberg disease): In osteopetrosis there is a defect in the normal process of bone resorption, resulting in excessive accumulation of dense, brittle bone tissue. This leads to increased bone density and reduced bone marrow space. The term "marble bone" refers to the appearance of the bones on imaging studies, which appear dense and resemble marble. Osteopetrosis can be inherited as an autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant condition and can manifest with various symptoms such as fractures, anemia, and impaired vision or hearing.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding rheumatoid nodules?

choices.text: Tender, located on extensor surface and seen with arthritis
Non tender, located on extensor surface and seen with arthritis
Non tender, located on flexor surface and seen with arthritis
Tender, located on flexor surface and seen with arthritis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Non tender, located on extensor surface and seen with arthritis:

  • Rheumatoid nodules are subcutaneous nodules characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis. They are usually painless (non-tender) and are typically found over bony prominences, especially on the extensor surfaces of joints, such as the elbows. Rheumatoid nodules result from the accumulation of inflammatory cells and fibrous tissue and are a specific clinical manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A triad of asthma, systemic vasculitis and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Churg Strauss Syndrome:

  • Churg Strauss syndrome, also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), is a rare autoimmune condition characterized by a triad of symptoms including asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis 
  • Features of EPGA are:
    • Eosinophilic vasculitis that involves multiple organ systems
    • Asthma
    • Peripheral Eosinophilia
    • Neuropathy
    • Pulmonary infiltrates
    • Paranasal sinus abnormalities

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a young male patient who experiences drooping eyelids that worsens as the day progresses, along with increased fatigue towards the end of the day which improves with rest? Additionally, the patient notices a significant decrease in drooping when placing an ice pack over their eyes.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Myasthenia gravis:

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that affects the neuromuscular junction, causing muscle weakness and fatigue. It is caused by antibodies that attack the acetylcholine receptors on the muscle, leading to a decrease in the number of available receptors and impaired nerve transmission. Ptosis, or drooping of the eyelid, is a common symptom. The ptosis tends to worsen through the day as more acetylcholine receptors are involved. Patients may also experience double vision, difficulty speaking or swallowing, and weakness in the limbs. 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Anti-centromere antibodies are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Scleroderma:

  • Anti-centromere antibodies are strongly associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), specifically the limited cutaneous form of the disease known as limited systemic sclerosis or CREST syndrome.
  • These antibodies are found in approximately 60-80% of patients with limited systemic sclerosis/CREST syndrome.
  • Anti-centromere antibodies are considered a specific marker for this subtype of systemic sclerosis.

Incorrect Options:

  • Anti-centromere antibodies are not seen in options A, B, and C.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is not used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Febuxostat:

  • Febuxostat is not used in the treatment of RA. It is a medication primarily used for the management of hyperuricemia (elevated levels of uric acid) in patients with gout. It works by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, which is involved in the production of uric acid. While gout and RA are both inflammatory conditions, the use of febuxostat is not considered a standard treatment for RA.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are used in the management of patients with rehumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient's hands is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rheumatoid Arthritis:

  • In the given scenario, the patient is presenting with chronic pain in the small joints of the hands, along with stiffness of the joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient's hands is consistent with the characteristic findings seen in Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA).
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints. It typically presents with symmetrical involvement of the small joints, such as those in the hands and wrists. The characteristic features of RA include joint pain, swelling, and morning stiffness that lasts for at least one hour. The image provided shows the presence of joint swelling, deformities (such as ulnar deviation and swan neck deformity), and changes in the finger joints, which are commonly seen in RA.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage. While it can also affect the small joints of the hands, the image and the clinical features described in the scenario are more indicative of Rheumatoid Arthritis. Osteoarthritis also does not present with symmetric involvement of joints unlike RA.

Option C - Complex Regional Pain Syndrome: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome, also known as Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy, is a condition characterized by chronic pain, swelling, and changes in skin color and temperature in the affected limb. The presentation and image provided in the scenario are not consistent with Complex Regional Pain Syndrome.

Option D - Villonodular Synovitis: Villonodular Synovitis is a rare condition characterized by the proliferation of synovial tissue in joints, tendon sheaths, or bursae. While it can lead to joint pain and swelling, it typically presents with localized findings and is less likely to involve multiple small joints as seen in the image.

questions.text: A female patient presents with fever, oral ulcer, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Systemic lupus erythematosus:

  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs and systems, including the skin, joints, kidneys, heart, and lungs. The butterfly rash, also known as malar rash, is a hallmark feature of SLE and typically appears on the face over the cheeks and bridge of the nose.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis has been treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine:

  • When a patient with rheumatoid arthritis shows inadequate response to initial therapy with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids, the addition of other disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) is often recommended. Sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine are commonly used DMARDs and can be added to the treatment regimen to improve disease control.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which is the most specific antibody in systemic sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anti-topoisomerase:

  • Anti-topoisomerase (Anti-Scl-70) antibodies are highly specific for systemic sclerosis, particularly its diffuse cutaneous subtype.
  • These antibodies target an enzyme called topoisomerase I, which is involved in DNA replication and repair.
  • The presence of anti-topoisomerase antibodies is strongly associated with skin involvement and internal organ complications in systemic sclerosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anti-DNA:

  • Anti-DNA antibodies are typically associated with autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) rather than systemic sclerosis.
  • While anti-DNA antibodies may be present in some cases of systemic sclerosis, they are not considered specific to the disease.

Option C - ANA:

  • ANA (antinuclear antibodies) is a general term for antibodies that target components within the cell nucleus.
  • While ANA can be detected in various autoimmune diseases, including systemic sclerosis, it is not specific to the condition.
  • ANA testing is often used as a screening tool to indicate the presence of an autoimmune process, but it does not provide a definitive diagnosis on its own.

Option D - Anti-Ro:

  • Anti-Ro (SS-A) antibodies are associated with various autoimmune conditions, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and Sjögren's syndrome.
  • While they may occasionally be detected in systemic sclerosis, they are not specific to the disease.

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - High glucose:

  • High glucose levels are typically not a characteristic feature of pleural effusion in rheumatoid arthritis. Elevated glucose levels in pleural fluid are commonly associated with conditions such as bacterial infections or malignancies. Rheumatoid effusion is usually associated with glucose <40 mg/dL.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - RA factor: RA factor (rheumatoid factor) is an autoantibody commonly found in the blood of individuals with rheumatoid arthritis. It can also be detected in the pleural effusion fluid of RA patients.

Option C - Cholesterol crystals: Cholesterol crystals can be present in the pleural effusion fluid of rheumatoid arthritis patients. These crystals may form due to inflammation and the breakdown of cellular membranes.

Option D - High LDH: High LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) levels are commonly seen in pleural effusions, including those associated with rheumatoid arthritis. LDH is an enzyme released from damaged or inflamed cells, and its elevation in the pleural fluid can indicate inflammation or tissue damage.
